snippet: Repeated failure to launch a nuclear missile could have sexual overtones.
abstract: News analysis; sexual innuendo has long accompanied talk of nuclear bombs, but North Korea's many failed attempts to launch a missile capable of carrying a nuclear payload has begun to elicit many allusions to sexual dysfunction. Photo (M)1
lead_paragraph: ''IT'S a boy,'' Edward Teller exulted after the world's first hydrogen bomb exploded in 1952 with a force 1,000 times more powerful than the bomb that destroyed Hiroshima. From the start, the nuclear era seethed with sexual allusions. Military officers joked about the phallic symbolism of their big missiles and warheads -- and of emasculating the enemy. ''Dr. Strangelove'' mocked the idea with big cigars and an excited man riding into the thermonuclear sunset with a bomb tucked between his legs.
